elements.content: Single crystals of [iPrMgCl­(THF)]2[MgCl2(THF)2]2 were obtained by layering a THF solution of the “turbo Grignard” iPrMgCl·LiCl with Et2O at ambient temperature. The isolated 1:1 Grignard–MgCl2 adduct is isostructural with crystalline compounds which were obtained from pure RMgCl solutions (R = Me, tBu, Ph, Bn). The structure of [iPrMgCl­(THF)]2[MgCl2(THF)2]2 reveals an open-cube motif (monoclinic, P21/c). When dioxane was added to a THF solution of iPrMgCl·LiCl, single crystals of [LiCl­(THF)2]2 and [iPr2Mg­(dioxane)]∞ (monoclinic, C2/c) were isolated. From 1:1 mixtures of (Me3Si)2CHMgCl (DisylMgCl) and LiCl (prepared analogously to iPrMgCl·LiCl) two different Grignard compounds, the monomer [DisylMgCl­(THF)2] (monoclinic, P21) and the dimer [DisylMgCl­(THF)]2 (monoclinic, P21/c), were isolated as single crystals. During our studies, two oxidation products of iPrMgCl and DisylMgCl, respectively, resulting from oxygen insertion, were obtained and structurally characterized. Colorless plates of [iPrMg­(OiPr)]4 (monoclinic, P21/m) grew from a THF/benzene solution. The dimeric alkoxide {[DisylOMgCl]­[LiCl­(THF)2]}2 (monoclinic, C2/c), which was obtained from DisylMgCl·LiCl by oxidation through residual oxygen, displays the only structure in which incorporation of LiCl in the molecular framework of a Mg alkoxide was observed.

elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In addition to organolithium compounds, Grignard reagents RMgX are among the most widely used reactive reagents in synthesis. It is therefore not surprising that much effort has been devoted to structural elucidation both in the solid state and in solution, since knowing the structure of highly reactive reagents is of essential importance when it comes to understanding the principles governing the high reactivity. When the structural characteristics of these compounds are understood, tuning of the reactivity becomes possible. This holds especially true for the "turbo Grignard" reagent iPrMgCl⋅LiCl (1(  i  Pr)⋅LiCl), introduced by Knochel et al., which possesses a high kinetic basicity, favoring halogen/magnesium exchange on substituted aromatic and heteroaromatic halides over nucleophilic attack on sensitive functional groups such as cyano, ester, etc. Furthermore, the solubility of the resulting arylmagnesium species is improved, due to the presence of LiCl.

elements.content: However, up to now only a suggestion of the mode of action of LiCl on the Grignard reagent has been made in the literature: namely, deaggregation of RMgX oligomers and coordination of LiCl with formation of a four-membered MgClLiCl ring in 1·LiCl. This is supposed to give magnesiate character to the Grignard reagent in the sense of a [Li]+[RMgCl2]− ion pair. Since magnesiates seem to be more reactive than their corresponding neutral Grignard counterparts in halogen/magnesium exchange, this explanation is reasonable. Nonetheless, up to now no X-ray crystallographic evidence of this perspective has been found. In this context it should be noted here that for the related “turbo Hauser” base (TMP)­MgCl·LiCl (TMP = 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidyl) crystallographic proof supporting this coordination mode exists. In the solid state 1­(TMP)·LiCl actually exists in the proposed MgClLiCl four-membered-ring structure. Furthermore, a heavy derivative of the “turbo Grignard”, namely (Me3Si)3CMg­(THF)­Br·LiBr­(THF)2, also forms MgBrLiBr rings in the solid state. However, the structural motif found in (TMP)­MgCl·LiCl and (Me3Si)3CMg­(THF)­Br·LiBr­(THF)2 otherwise does not have much prevalence in the literature.
elements.clean_text: However, up to now only a suggestion of the mode of action of LiCl on the Grignard reagent has been made in the literature: namely, deaggregation of RMgX oligomers and coordination of LiCl with formation of a four-membered MgClLiCl ring in 1⋅LiCl. This is supposed to give magnesiate character to the Grignard reagent in the sense of a [Li]+[RMgCl2]- ion pair. Since magnesiates seem to be more reactive than their corresponding neutral Grignard counterparts in halogen/magnesium exchange, this explanation is reasonable. Nonetheless, up to now no X-ray crystallographic evidence of this perspective has been found. In this context it should be noted here that for the related "turbo Hauser" base (TMP)MgCl⋅LiCl (TMP = 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidyl) crystallographic proof supporting this coordination mode exists. In the solid state 1(TMP)⋅LiCl actually exists in the proposed MgClLiCl four-membered-ring structure. Furthermore, a heavy derivative of the "turbo Grignard", namely (Me3Si)3CMg(THF)Br⋅LiBr(THF)2, also forms MgBrLiBr rings in the solid state. However, the structural motif found in (TMP)MgCl⋅LiCl and (Me3Si)3CMg(THF)Br⋅LiBr(THF)2 otherwise does not have much prevalence in the literature.

elements.content: We firmly believe that detailed structural information concerning the extent of coordination and association in organometallic compounds is important in understanding their chemical reactivity. Therefore, we started a program aimed at structurally characterizing 1­( i Pr)·LiCl and 1­(Disyl)·LiCl (Disyl = (Me3Si)2CH), as a heavy congener, to find a structural proof for the proposed LiCl degradation/magnesiate effect. The results achieved so far are reported in this paper.

elements.content: Solutions of 1­(iPr)·LiCl in THF were prepared as described in the literature and directly used for this structural study. Cooling down an approximately 1 M solution of the “turbo-Grignard” to −80 °C led reproducibly to the crystallization of large crops of MgCl2(THF)4, different polymorphs of which have already been described. When the temperature was raised, complete redissolution was observed. When the supernatant was separated at low temperature and further cooled to −80 °C, no more crystalline precipitates were obtained. Low-temperature crystallization techniques were therefore not further pursued.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Classical Turbo Grignard 1(iPr)⋅LiCl 

Solutions of 1(iPr)⋅LiCl in THF were prepared as described in the literature and directly used for this structural study. Cooling down an approximately 1 M solution of the "turbo-Grignard" to -80 °C led reproducibly to the crystallization of large crops of MgCl2(THF)4, different polymorphs of which have already been described. When the temperature was raised, complete redissolution was observed. When the supernatant was separated at low temperature and further cooled to -80 °C, no more crystalline precipitates were obtained. Low-temperature crystallization techniques were therefore not further pursued.

elements.content: By layering a THF solution of 1­( i Pr)·LiCl with Et2O, colorless single crystals suitable for a structure determination were obtained. However, these crystals did not incorporate LiCl, as evidenced by X-ray crystallography. Instead, the MgCl2 adduct [iPrMgCl­(THF)]2[MgCl2(THF)2]2 (3­( i Pr)) with an open-cube structure was formed (Figure , Chart , Table 1S ()). Structures analogous to that of 3­( i Pr) are found in compounds which crystallize from RMgCl solutions that do not contain LiCl. As shown in Scheme , there is an equilibrium between the Grignard compounds RMgCl (R = Me, tBu, Ph, Bn) on the one hand and diorganylmagnesium (2) and MgCl2 adducts (3) on the other hand. This finding can be regarded as an extension of the Schlenk equilibrium. A discussion of the key structural parameters of 3­( i Pr) is provided in the .

elements.clean_text: 1  RMgCl in Donor Solvents

elements.content: In the literature it was postulated that, in the presence of stoichiometric LiCl, aggregates of Grignard reagents are broken down into monomeric LiCl adducts of RMgCl, 1·LiCl, in which two μ2-chloro ligands in four-membered MgClLiCl rings are present (Scheme ). However, the connectivity in the single crystals that we obtained from a THF solution of the “turbo Grignard” 1­( i Pr)·LiCl is similar to that in the crystals grown from plain RMgCl (R = Me, tBu, Ph, Bn) solutions, namely dimeric RMgCl·MgCl2 adducts (cf. 3, Chart ). Thereby MgCl2 acts in a manner as proposed for LiCl. This could well be an effect of the stronger Lewis acidity of the Mg center in MgCl2 in comparison to the Li cation in LiCl. In this context it should be mentioned that mass spectrometric investigations of RMgCl (R = Me, tBu, Ph, Bn) solutions in THF also showed the existence of these MgCl2 adducts in solution. Apparently the structure type 3 not only is favored in the solid state but also prevails in solution. As shown in Chart , when the ratio of RMgCl and MgCl2 is 1:2, dianionic dimers with the constitution [R2MgCl]2 2– were found in the solid state. Neutral dimers [RMgCl­(Do)]2 (1b, Do = donor; Chart ) were not observed in this case (R = Me, tBu, Ph, Bn). Apparently the formation of complexes of type 3 is favored over simple dimerization of neutral RMgCl molecules, presumably once again due to the stronger Lewis acidity of MgCl2 over that of RMgCl.

elements.clean_text: 2  Turbo Grignard

elements.content: In an attempt to drive the equilibrium of 1­( i Pr)·LiCl to the LiCl adduct side, dioxane was added to a THF solution of the “turbo Grignard” to precipitate MgCl2 as its dioxane-bridged adduct. As already stated, this should enforce the formation of an “anion Schlenk equilibrium” in which the magnesiate [Li]+[R2MgCl]− is the major basic constituent. We furthermore reasoned that this should also hamper the formation of the MgCl2 adduct 3­( i Pr), since MgCl2 is removed from the equilibrium, leaving behind a higher local concentration of LiCl. After separation of the colorless powder (MgCl2·(dioxane)) different crystallization attempts were undertaken with the supernatant. However, no adduct of the Grignard reagent 1­( i Pr) with LiCl was observed and the only isolable crystalline products were [LiCl­(THF)2]2 (from THF/dioxane at −80 °C) and [iPr2Mg­(dioxane)] ∞ (2­( i Pr), from THF/dioxane by slow evaporation; (Scheme ) Figure 1S, Table 1S ()). Apparently, no lithium magnesiate of the type [Li]+[R2MgCl] – was formed in single-crystal form. Addition of other antisolvents (hexane, pentane, Et2O, etc.) to the THF/dioxane mixture yielded powdered samples, with insufficient crystallinity.

elements.content: The structure determination of [LiCl­(THF)2]2 was already reported, and as reported, we also found the crystals grown from the mixed THF/dioxane solvent system at −80 °C to be highly temperature-labile. Even upon a slight increase in temperature, melting occurred instantly. Picking and mounting the crystals had to be performed without letting the involved components (oil, spatula, object slide, glass fiber) warm up. Metric parameters are the same as already reported and therefore do not merit discussion.

elements.clean_text: 4  Reaction of RMgCl with Oxygen

elements.content: Throughout the development of organometallic chemistry, incorporation of oxygen into highly reactive species was recognized as a problem and compounds containing oxide, peroxide, alkoxide, and alkyl peroxide substituents were all isolated by chance from supposedly oxygen-free systems. During our studies on 1­( i Pr)·LiCl, in one instance, a partially oxidized product, resulting from oxygen insertion, was isolated and structurally characterized. Colorless plates of [iPrMg­(OiPr)]4 (7­( i Pr); Figure 3S, Table 2S ()) were isolated from a THF/benzene solution of 1­( i Pr)·LiCl (Scheme ). Apparently traces of residual dioxygen are responsible for the formation of 6­( i Pr), which then forms a complex with 1­( i Pr). Analytical data of 7­( i Pr) were already reported, but no X-ray crystallographic characteristics were given; therefore, the solid-state structure of 7­( i Pr) is discussed in the .

elements.content: Reasoning that a heavier, less polar Grignard reagent might provide a greater crystallinity and better solubility in apolar solvents, we prepared DisylMgCl·LiCl (1­(Disyl)·LiCl; Disyl = (Me3Si)2CH) in the same fashion as 1­(iPr)·LiCl, starting from DisylCl and Mg. Solutions of 1­(Disyl)·LiCl were then subjected to a wide variety of crystallization procedures, and only the attempts yielding crystalline material are presented here.
elements.clean_text:
Heavy Analogue of the Turbo Grignard

Reasoning that a heavier, less polar Grignard reagent might provide a greater crystallinity and better solubility in apolar solvents, we prepared DisylMgCl⋅LiCl (1(Disyl)⋅LiCl; Disyl = (Me3Si)2CH) in the same fashion as 1(iPr)⋅LiCl, starting from DisylCl and Mg. Solutions of 1(Disyl)⋅LiCl were then subjected to a wide variety of crystallization procedures, and only the attempts yielding crystalline material are presented here.

elements.content: When a THF solution of 1­(Disyl)·LiCl was evaporated to dryness, a colorless powder was obtained, which was partially soluble in hexane. Extracting this powder with hexane and cooling the extract to −30 °C yielded the dimeric, crystalline Grignard reagent [DisylMgCl­(THF)]2 (1b­(Disyl); Figure 4S, Table 1S ()), the structure of which is discussed below. Obviously also in this case, the incorporation of LiCl in the solid-state structure is unfavorable. Attempts to crystallize the material from other extraction solvents proved to be unsuccessful, whereas THF solutions yielded only noncrystalline material upon evaporation or layering with different antisolvents (pentane, hexane, Et2O, benzene, etc.).
elements.clean_text: When a THF solution of 1(Disyl)⋅LiCl was evaporated to dryness, a colorless powder was obtained, which was partially soluble in hexane. Extracting this powder with hexane and cooling the extract to -30 °C yielded the dimeric, crystalline Grignard reagent [DisylMgCl(THF)]2 (1b(Disyl); Figure 4S, Table 1S ()), the structure of which is discussed below. Obviously also in this case, the incorporation of LiCl in the solid-state structure is unfavorable. Attempts to crystallize the material from other extraction solvents proved to be unsuccessful, whereas THF solutions yielded only noncrystalline material upon evaporation or layering with different antisolvents (pentane, hexane, Et2O, benzene, etc.).

elements.content: In another batch, following the same procedure as for 1b­(Disyl), we obtained the monomeric compound [DisylMgCl­(THF)2] (1a­(Disyl), (right)), once again highlighting the broad structural diversity of Grignard reagents in the solid state, as well as the subtle effects governing the formation of different crystalline forms. The data quality of 1a­(Disyl) was rather poor but was sufficient to unequivocally determine the connectivity and identity of all atoms.
elements.clean_text: In another batch, following the same procedure as for 1b(Disyl), we obtained the monomeric compound [DisylMgCl(THF)2] (1a(Disyl),  (right)), once again highlighting the broad structural diversity of Grignard reagents in the solid state, as well as the subtle effects governing the formation of different crystalline forms. The data quality of 1a(Disyl) was rather poor but was sufficient to unequivocally determine the connectivity and identity of all atoms.

elements.content: Also in the case of the heavy “turbo Grignard” 1­(Disyl)·LiCl we could isolate an oxidation product in one instance. Single crystals of {[DisylOMgCl]­[LiCl­(THF)2]}2 (6­(Disyl)·LiCl) were grown from hexane at −30 °C. The dimeric alkoxide 6­(Disyl)·LiCl (Figure , Table 2S ()) represents the only compound in which we ever observed incorporation of LiCl in the molecular framework in the course of this study. The proposed μ2 coordination of two chloro ligands for [RMgCl·LiCl], forming four-membered MgClLiCl rings, is found in this case and is further discussed in the .

To fully characterize 6­(Disyl)·LiCl, attempts to deliberately oxidize 1­(Disyl)·LiCl were undertaken. A THF solution of 1­(Disyl)·LiCl was exposed to an atmosphere of N2O; however, no conversion of the starting material could be observed, even after 48 h. The reluctance to react with an electrophilic oxygen source is remarkable and might hint at a different mode of action for “turbo Grignard” reagents in halogen/magnesium exchange. Classically it is believed that nucleophilic attack of the organyl on the halogen atom is involved in the exchange reaction. If this is true, the question arises as to why apparently less nucleophilic “turbo Grignard” reagents (broad tolerance toward a variety of highly electrophilic functional groups) are more active in halogen/magnesium exchange than their corresponding standard Grignard reagents.

elements.content: Since no reaction of 1­(Disyl)·LiCl with N2O took place, dioxygen was bubbled through a THF solution of 1­(Disyl)·LiCl in THF at −78 °C for 1 h in order to obtain the desired 6­(Disyl)·LiCl. However, NMR spectroscopic investigation of the crude product after evaporation of the solvent showed several decomposition products (e.g., insertion products of O2 into the Si–C bond). These products were not further characterized. More success was achieved when a THF solution of 1­(Disyl)·LiCl in THF was exposed to an atmosphere of dry ambient air (dried over molecular sieves 4 Å). After 2 days NMR spectroscopy of the crude product showed a 1:5 mixture of the desired 6­(Disyl)·LiCl and unreacted 1­(Disyl)·LiCl as the main constituents along with some side products, presumably due to unselective oxidation. Apparently with lower dioxygen concentrations a more selective and mild reaction is possible, at the expense of a longer reaction time.

elements.content: Since oxygen is known to react with organometallic reagents by electron transfer processes, and 1­(Disyl)·LiCl reacted, albeit unselectively, with O2, it is plausible to at least assume the possibility of an electron-based reactivity for “turbo Grignard” reagents. This reducing ability might also apply to halogen/magnesium exchange reaction and would provide a convenient explanation of the observed high activity in halogen/magnesium exchange along with the high functional group tolerance.

elements.content: In the course of this study aimed at finding crystallographic proof for the proposed solid-state structure of the “turbo Grignard” reagent 1­( i Pr)·LiCl and its heavy relative 1­(Disyl)·LiCl, we were able to obtain crystallographic data for three highly reactive organometallic species, namely [iPrMgCl­(THF)]2[MgCl2(THF)2]2 (3­( i Pr); Figure ), [iPr2Mg­(dioxane)]∞ (2­( i Pr); ), and [DisylMgCl­(THF)]2 (1b­(Disyl); ), as well as two of their (partial) oxidation products [iPrMg­(OiPr)]4 (7­( i Pr); ) and {[DisylOMgCl]­[LiCl­(THF)2]}2 (6­(Disyl)·LiCl; Figure ) by a variety of crystallization techniques. These data give insight into the rich solid-state chemistry of Grignard reagents, as well as the structural diversity of their oxidation products and help to fill in some of the blank spots on the map of crystallographically characterized Grignard reagents.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In the course of this study aimed at finding crystallographic proof for the proposed solid-state structure of the "turbo Grignard" reagent 1(  i  Pr)⋅LiCl  and its heavy relative 1(Disyl)⋅LiCl, we were able to obtain crystallographic data for three highly reactive organometallic species, namely [iPrMgCl(THF)]2[MgCl2(THF)2]2 (3(  i  Pr); Figure ), [iPr2Mg(dioxane)]∞ (2(  i  Pr); ), and [DisylMgCl(THF)]2 (1b(Disyl); ), as well as two of their (partial) oxidation products [iPrMg(OiPr)]4 (7(  i  Pr); ) and {[DisylOMgCl][LiCl(THF)2]}2 (6(Disyl)⋅LiCl; Figure ) by a variety of crystallization techniques. These data give insight into the rich solid-state chemistry of Grignard reagents, as well as the structural diversity of their oxidation products and help to fill in some of the blank spots on the map of crystallographically characterized Grignard reagents.

elements.content: Unfortunately we were unable to obtain the proposed RMgCl·LiCl structure and merely found LiCl incorporation in a single case (6­(Disyl)·LiCl). This raises the question whether the proposed LiCl aggregated arrangement is really stable for light organometallic derivatives or if it is only a transient species, as the only observed “turbo Grignard” reagent with this proposed structure is [(Me3Si)3CMgBr­(THF)]­[LiBr­(THF)2]. Perhaps if sterics permit (small organic substituents), the stronger Lewis acid MgCl2 forms an adduct preferred over the smaller LiCl.

Perhaps if sterics permit (small organic substituents), the stronger Lewis acid MgCl2 forms an adduct preferred over the smaller LiCl.

elements.content: The lack of reactivity of 1­(Disyl)·LiCl toward N2O and the rather unselective reaction with O2 might hint at a reductive electron transfer mechanism in the halogen/magnesium exchange using “turbo Grignard” bases. It can however be concluded that, in contrast to organolithium compounds, a direct correlation between the solid-state structure and the reactivity in solution is rather dubious.

Experimental Section

General Procedures

All reactions and manipulations were carried out under dry, oxygen-free nitrogen by using standard Schlenk ware or in an argon-filled M. Braun glovebox. THF, [D8]THF, Et2O, pentane, dioxane, benzene, and [D6]benzene were stirred over sodium/benzophenone and distilled prior to use. The NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker AM 250, DPX 250, Avance 300, and Avance 400 spectrometers. NMR chemical shifts are reported in ppm and referenced to external tetramethylsilane (1H, 13C, 29Si) or LiBr in D2O (7Li). Abbreviations: s, singlet; d, doublet; sept, septet; mult, multiplet; br, broad.

X-ray Crystallography of 1a(Disyl), 1b(Disyl), 2(iPr), 3(iPr), 6(Disyl)⋅LiCl, 7(iPr), and [LiCl(THF)2]2 

All crystals were measured on a STOE IPDS-II diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation. An empirical absorption correction with the program PLATON was performed for all structures. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with full-matrix least squares on F 2 using the program SHELXL97.

elements.content: One of the isopropyl groups in 7­( i Pr) is disordered over two positions with a site occupation factor of 0.51(2) for the major occupied site. The disordered atoms were just isotropically refined, and equivalent C–C distances were restrained to be equal. Two THF rings in 3­( i Pr) are disordered over two positions with site occupation factors of 0.55(2) and 0.60(2) for the major occupied sites. The disordered atoms were just isotropically refined. The displacement parameters of the carbon atoms in 1a­(Disyl) were restrained to an isotropic behavior. The two THF rings in 6­(Disyl)·LiCl are disordered over two positions with site occupation factors of 0.563(7) and 0.504(7) for the major occupied sites. All the disordered atoms were just isotropically refined, and equivalent distances and angles were restrained to be equal. Anal. Calcd for C7H19Cl2LiMgSi2⋅0.3THF (261.55 + 21.63): C, 34.78; H, 7.62. Found: C, 34.88; H, 7.29.

Oxidation of [DisylMgCl⋅LiCl] to 6(Disyl)⋅LiCl 

[DisylMgCl⋅LiCl] (531 mg, 2.41 mmol, 0.86 mm) in THF was placed in an atmosphere of dry air (obtained by drying at ambient atmosphere over activated MS 4 Å) and the mixture stirred vigorously for 48 h. NMR spectroscopic analysis of the residue obtained upon evaporation of the solvent showed remaining starting material and the desired oxidation product in a ratio of 1:5 as the main constituents along with several minor side products, presumably due to overoxidation. 1H NMR (400.1 MHz, [D8]THF): δ 0.06 (s, 18 H; Si(CH3)3), 3.23 (s, 1 H; CH). 13C{1H} NMR (75.4 MHz, [D8]THF): δ  -0.67 (Si(CH3)3), 59.67 (CH). 7Li NMR (116.6 MHz, [D8]THF): δ 2.11. 29Si{1H} NMR (59.6 MHz, [D8]THF): δ 2.04 (Si(CH3)3).
